subject: Pop domain-id from the config if we infer values
commit_message:
Pop domain-id from the config if we infer values

If the user specifies a project_{name,id}, then we currently infer that
a domain_{name,id} is meant to be shorthand for user_domain_{name,id} and
project_domain_{name,id}. However, in other contexts, domain_id is a
perfectly valid value to pass to the auth plugins - such as when doing
domain-scoped activities.

The problem that was uncovered by the correction of argument precedence
is that we didn't pop the domain-id out of the root config dict, so if a
user set OS_DOMAIN_ID in the environment, we were happily setting the
user and project versions, but then leaving domain_id set as well. This
then meant that when we do the pass to pull valid arguments from the
root dict to the auth dict, we also pulled in domain_id - which led to
the error:

  AuthorizationFailure: Authentication cannot be scoped to multiple
  targets. Pick one of: project, domain, trust or unscoped

Popping the value from the root dict causes the things to work as
documented.

Change-Id: I6d208e5ec4115d2e72d30b2fedc90a81ea754d5a

subject: Fix FC multipath rescan
commit_message:
Fix FC multipath rescan

Fiber Chanel multipath rescan uses wildcards for the host rescan, which
can end up recreating devices that had just been removed if there's a
race condition between the removal of a SCSI device and the connection
of a volume.

The race condition happens if a rescan done when attaching happens right
between us removing the path and removing the lun, because the rescan
will add not only the new path we are attaching, but the old path we are
removing, since the lun still hasn't been removed.

This would leave orphaned devices that pollute our environment and will
be recognized as down paths when the storage controller reuses the same
WWID.

This patch narrows the rescan to only rescan for the specific lun
number, and if possible it also filters the rescan by HBA channel and
SCSI target ID.

We only filter by HBA channel and SCSI target ID when we can find this
information, and that is when the FC storage servers implement a single
WWNN for all ports.

Change-Id: Id6ed98d3fb8b4b980de86256dec8eeda84562c98
Closes-Bug: #1608614

Introduce read-only mode for the database

One of the outcomes of the keystone midcycle was the idea for a
read-only mode, which would allow keystone to continue serving 99% of
keystone's real world usage patterns (and possibly 100% during a rolling
upgrade process), while the underlying database schema is being live
migrated.

even partially migrated, database without interfering in the upgrade
process by racing the data migration process, and the new code does not
have to know how to read and write two different schemas (and any

subject: Update in-memory firewall for only requested ports
commit_message:
Update in-memory firewall for only requested ports

When applying port filters for the requested ports,
current implementation
1) removes in-memory firewall rules for all "existing" ports i.e
   for all ports on that agent
2) adds (or removes) requested ports to(from) "existing" ports
3) then creates in-memory firewall rules for these "existing" ports

But when the agent has large number of ports, this process will take
longer time. Instead of removing and then adding firewall rules for
all the ports, we directly update in-memory firewall rules with the
firewall rules of requested ports. This will save agents time spent
on processing in-memory firewall rules.

subject: [Urgent]Fix the integration test failure casused by http header processing
commit_message:
[Urgent]Fix the integration test failure casused by http header processing

1.What is the problem:
Python requests lib is used to forward the http request from the Cinder
API-GW to bottom Cinder. Now the latest version of the requests lib
add stricter header validity check: only bytes or string is allowed for
header item's value, other value will lead to exception, even for "None".
But Cinder client will pass some header items with "None" value in the
api request to Cinder API-GW, thus lead to the exception in Cinder API-GW
when forwarding the request to the bottom Cinder via requests lib, which
lead to the integration failed, and block any patch to be merged.

2.What's need to be fixed:
Remove(clean) the invalid header items in the request to the bottom
Cinder, in which the python requests lib is used. So that integration
test can pass, and make patch being able to be merged.

3.What is the purpose of this patch set:
Fix the integration test failure issue casued by strict validity check
in http header processing.

subject: Set migration status to 'error' on live-migration failure
commit_message:
Set migration status to 'error' on live-migration failure

(A) In resize, confirm-resize and revert-resize operation, migration status
is marked as 'error' in case of failure for respective operation.

Migration object support is added in live-migration operation, which mark
migration status to 'failed' if live-migration operation fails in-between.

To make live-migration consistent with resize, confirm-resize and revert-
resize operation, it needs to mark migration status to 'error' instead of
'failed' in case of failure.

(B) Apart from consistency, proposed change fixes issue (similar to [1])
which might occur on live-migration failure as follows:
If live-migration fails (which sets migration status to 'failed') after
copying instance files from source to dest node and then user request for
instance deletion. In that case, delete api will only remove instance
files from instance.host and not from other host (which could be either
source or dest node but not instance.host). Since instance is already
deleted, instance files will remain on other host (not instance.host).

Set migration status to 'error' on live-migration failure, so that
periodic task _cleanup_incomplete_migrations [2] will remove orphaned
instance files from compute nodes after instance deletion in above case.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1392527
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/219299/

DocImpact: On live-migration failure, set migration status to 'error'
instead of 'failed'.

Change-Id: I7a0c5a32349b0d3604802d22e83a3c2dab4b1370
Closes-Bug: 1470420

subject: rt: Pass the nodename to RT.instance_claim()
commit_message:
rt: Pass the nodename to RT.instance_claim()

We want to eventually stop treating the Ironic nodename as a "special"
kind of unicorn resource in the system. To get there, we need to
decouple the (host, nodename) state in the nova-compute resource
tracker. And in order to do that, we first need to stop creating a
resource tracker instance on the nova-compute for every Ironic bare
metal resource node.

So, in this patch we begin that process by changing the RT's
instance_claim() method to have a nodename parameter and use that
parameter instead of the RT's nodename attribute. We can't yet remove
the RT.nodename attribute because resize_claim() and rebuild_claim()
still need to accept a nodename parameter, which we do in the next
patch, followed by a patch that completes the removal entirely of the
need to have multiple resource tracker instances in the nova-compute
manager.

Change-Id: I57786e9ca021f19b3fc364ad43f7eb32cae80149
blueprint: generic-resource-pools

subject: rt: Pass nodename to internal RT methods
commit_message:
rt: Pass nodename to internal RT methods

The end goal of this patch series is to remove the resource tracker's
nodename attribute and have the resource tracker treat Ironic baremetal
resource nodes like any other consumable resource in the system. Before
we get to that point, though, we need to perform some surgery on the
resource tracker to pass a nodename parameter to a number of methods.
The first one up is the simple internal methods:

- _set_instance_host_and_nodename()
- _create_migration()
- _claim_existing_migraton()
- _move_claim()

blueprint: generic-resource-pools
